clinical_study.brief_title: Bilateral Knee Osteoarthritis: Intra-articular Injection of Filtered Autologous Adipose Tissue Versus Placebo
clinical_study.official_title: Randomized Double Blind Clinical Study on the Treatment of Bilateral Knee Arthrosis: Intra-articular Injection of Filtered Autologous Adipose Tissue Versus Placebo

brief_summary.textblock:
The purpose of the study is to assess the radiological and clinical outcomes comparing two different treatments (Filtered Autologous Adipose Tissue versus Placebo) in patients affecting bilateral knee osteoarthritis.
After be randomized, every patient will be treated in both legs, one leg with Adipose Tissue and the other one with Placebo.

detailed_description.textblock:
All patients who meet the inclusion criteria and giving written informed consent will be randomized.
Every patient will be treated with a single injection of Filtered Autologous Adipose Tissue in one knee and single injection of Placebo in the other, based on the randomization.
After the treatment patients will be followed up to 24 months.

primary_outcome.measure: Western Ontario and McMaster Universities Osteoarthritis Index (WOMAC)
primary_outcome.description: It is a 0 - 100 standardized questionnaire widely used for the evaluation of patients with knee osteoarthrosis. The questionnaire is made by three subscale: Pain (5 questions ranging from 0 - 20), Stiffness (2 questions ranging from 0 - 8) and Function (17 questions ranging from 0 - 68).

secondary_outcome.measure: Subjective International Knee Documentation Committee (IKDC - subjective score)
secondary_outcome.description: Questionnaire is specific for knee pathologies. it is composed by three subscales: Symptoms, Sport Activities and Knee Function. (Total score 0-100)

secondary_outcome.measure: Objective International Knee Documentation Committee (IKDC-Objective Score)
secondary_outcome.description: The presence of effusions and the degree of movement of the knee are evaluated, the worst value of one of these parameters determines the final value of the IKDC degree. There are four grades (A, B, C, D) which respectively identify a knee rated as normal, near normal, abnormal and severely abnormal;
